Spellcraft Overview.name: Spellcraft Overview
Spellcraft Overview.text:
Spellcraft is the particular art and theory of magic as implemented in the Crucible system. Proficiecy with spellcraft advances through Talents that are learned as part of character progression. The Crucible spellcraft system is designed to be dynamic and generative, allowing players who wish to focus their character on spellcasting to improvise and discover effective combinations and applications for their magical abilities.

The Spellcraft system is still a work-in-progress and, while functional, is expected to undergo substantial revision and iteration in future Crucible releases. The implementation of the Spellcraft system in Playtest One should provide insight into its mechanics and planned functionality.

Masterful Composition

Spellcraft allows characters to manifest magic by composing a spell using a @UUID[.p3hKRiZN3x0DEtyG]{Rune}, @UUID[.lhrYInsQ2f0YfhTu]{Gesture}, and optionally an @UUID[.ELOcfx6LPZMh74y8]{Inflection}.

  • Runes represent the base magical essence (such as Spirit or Flame), metaphysical concepts that combine to form the laws of reality.

  • Gestures represent the forming of the rune into a spell, using physical motion as a somatic component which shape (such as Create or Arrow) a Rune's power, causing it to act in a specific way.

  • Inflections represent a further change or modification (such as Quicken or Pull), and use vocalization to alter how a spell is formed.

As your character learns Talents which provide Spellcraft components, these components will appear on the Grimoire tab of your character sheet and become usable through the Cast a Spell action. The process of learning components and discovering new spell combinations is intended to provide a rewarding experience of magical experimentation and narrative development for characters which invest into Spellcraft.

It is useful to think of the rules and structure of the Spellcraft system linguistically. If you think of a spell as a sentence, each spell must have a Rune (noun) and a Gesture (verb), and may optionally include an Inflection (adjective/adverb) that modifies either.

Spells which attack an opponent follow the rules of @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.QhZgmBrdLAGwYy5c.JournalEntryPage.lZfPVvBSsCEqlte4]{Attack Rolls}, with changes to the Ability Bonus and Base Damage of the attack depending on the combination of Rune and Gesture used.

Example: Zarajah the Pyromancer

Zarajah is an ambitious Level 6 sorcerer who strives to master the arts of elemental magic. Zarajah knows the runes for Flame, Kinesis, and Lightning as well as gestures for Touch (automatically learned), Influence, and Arrow. Additionally, Zarajah has also learned the Quicken inflection. Using these components, Zarajah has access to 18 different combinations which form Spells.

Zarajah's favorite spell is Quickened Arrow of Flame which allows her to hurl a projectile of arcane fire at a single target up to 10 spaces distant at the cost of 1 Action and 2 Focus points. The Flame rune targets Reflex defense and deals Fire Damage to Health. Arrow and Flame both scale using Intellect, so the effectiveness of this spell scales using only Intellect as a single ability score.

When Zarajah casts a Quickened Arrow of Flame towards a swooping Manticore, she rolls a 28 on her spell attack roll, beating the Manticore's Reflex defense of 21. This 7 Overflow Damage is increased by the 10 Base Damage of the Arrow gesture, resulting in a total of 17 Fire Damage dealt to the foe.

Since this attack is also a Critical Hit, the Manticore bursts into flame due to Zarajah's Pyromancer talent which inflicts the Burning condition causing additional damage-over-time.

The Cost of Magic

Every magic spell has a cost- whether used within a combat situation or for out-of-combat benefits. Generally, this cost is paid in the form of @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6.JournalEntryPage.FmmADsI9qo1uIIT3#capacity-for-action]{Focus Points}, though in some situations the cost may use other resources or have other requirements.

As you construct your spells, the cost of the spell in Action Points and Focus Points may change based on your choice of @UUID[.p3hKRiZN3x0DEtyG]{Rune}, @UUID[.lhrYInsQ2f0YfhTu]{Gesture} and @UUID[.ELOcfx6LPZMh74y8]{Inflection}.

Runes.name: Runes
Runes.text:
Runes are the most basic metaphysical concept of magic. They are forces of nature, the building blocks of reality as we understand it. Understanding the Runes and their place in the way the world functions allows those with sufficient training to exert a level of influence over the Runes, using @UUID[.lhrYInsQ2f0YfhTu]{Gestures} to manifest powerful displays of magical prowess.

There are six Chaotic Runes and six Orderly Runes, forming a natural opposition to one another. Lesser Runes which are more closely associated with tangible, elemental forces (such as Flame and Frost, Life and Death), and Greater Runes which represent more abstract forces (such as Control and Spirit, Kinesis and Stasis).

Chaotic Runes

Lesser Runes

  • Flame - The chaotic force of elemental, thermal energy. The Flame rune governs fire and heat. It is opposed by the orderly rune of Frost.

  • Life - The chaotic force of creation, responsible for all living matter. The Life rune governs health and matters relating to biological growth. It is opposed by the orderly rune of Death.

  • Lightning - The chaotic force of raw, electrical energy. The Lightning rune governs sources of electrical energy and electrical discharge. It is opposed by the orderly rune of Earth.

Greater Runes

  • Illumination - The chaotic force of light and positive energy. The Illumination rune governs light and all of its properties. It is opposed by the orderly rune of Shadow.

  • Spirit - The chaotic force of emotion and willfulness. The Spirit rune governs matters related to emotional well-being as well as the soul. It is opposed by the orderly rune of Control.

  • Kinesis - The chaotic force of space and physical movement. The Kinesis rune governs all things related to the act of movement and physicality. It is opposed by the orderly rune of Stasis.

Orderly Runes

Lesser Runes

  • Death - The orderly force of destruction, responsible for the decay of all matter. The Death rune governs decay and destruction. It is opposed by the chaotic rune of Life.

  • Earth - The orderly force of elemental earth, responsible for physical matter. The Earth rune governs health and matters relating to biological growth. It is opposed by the chaotic rune of Lightning.

  • Frost - The orderly force of elemental, thermal energy. The Frost rune governs sources of ice and cold. It is opposed by the chaotic rune of Flame.

Greater Runes

  • Control - The orderly force of discipline and the mind. The Control rune governs thought, logic and reason. It is opposed by the chaotic rune of Spirit.

  • Shadow - The orderly force of darkness and negative energy. The Shadow rune governs darkness and all of its properties. It is opposed by the chaotic rune of Illumination.

  • Stasis - The orderly force of immutability and potential energy. The Stasis rune governs all things related to permanence and resistance to change. It is opposed by the chaotic rune of Kinesis.

Runic Mechanics

The choice of Rune used in the casting of a spell affects or determines a variety of aspects of the resulting spellcraft.

  • The conceptual essence of the magic.

  • Which other Rune is in opposition to this Spell.

  • One @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6.JournalEntryPage.RHCy135mF4EN1mWZ]{Ability Score} which defines half of the Spell Attack scaling formula.

  • The @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6.JournalEntryPage.alkVSDmt0ec5HBfE]{Defense} against which the spell is tested.

  • A @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6.JournalEntryPage.FmmADsI9qo1uIIT3]{Resource} the spell affects.

  • The @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6.JournalEntryPage.XDx0e2rZWcHLcfBt#damage-types]{Damage Type} that is dealt by the spell.

Gestures.name: Gestures
Gestures.text:
Gestures are the physical, somatic components required to invoke a rune for Spellcraft purposes. Gestures determine the shape a spell will take as it is translated from the raw magical energies governed by a Rune into a manifestation of that power. Gestures set particular properties of a magical spell, usually the cost in Action and Focus points, range (or size), targeting type, and shape. Gestures also determine one-half of the scaling damage formula, with Rune as the other half.

Arrow

1 Hand, 2 Action, 1 Focus

Hurl a projectile of magical power at a distant target. This might use the Lightning Rune to hurl a lightning bolt, or the Shadow rune to hurl a ball of devouring darkness.

Aspect

1 Hand, 2 Action, 1 Focus

Infuse the essence of a Rune into the self, empowering the physical form or psyche.

When you assume a certain Aspect, you become more closely attuned to the damage type of the Rune used in your spell. You gain +2 Resistance to that damage type, and deal an additional +2 Damage whenever dealing damage of that type.

Create

2 Hands, 2 Action, 1 Focus

Coalesce arcane power into tangible form, conjuring a Creation which appears in an adjacent space and joins Combat at Initiative 1.

Your Creation is a Minion of half your own Level chosen from the Summoned Creatures compendium pack corresponding to the Rune used in the spell.

Fan

1 Hand, 2 Action, 1 Focus

Focus the essence of a rune into a sweeping or splintered arc to strike multiple targets in close proximity. If used with Earth, this might hurl a spray of stone in an arc, while using it with Kinesis might carve a slice across multiple foes.

Influence

1 Hand, 2 Action, 1 Focus

Channel concentrated arcane energy through a single target via touch. If used with the rune of Life this would create a powerful healing effect, while used with the touch of Lightning would provide a powerful jolt of Electrical damage.

Pulse

2 Hands, 2 Action, 1 Focus

Emit a burst of Runic power in a circular wave that travels outward, with you at its center. A Pulse of Spirit might be used to bolster Morale for your allies, while a Death pulse might be used to deal Corruption damage to a group of enemies gathered around you.

Ray

1 Hand, 2 Action, 1 Focus

Focus the power of a Rune into a single point, expelling its energy into a ranged beam which rapidly travels a short distance to a targeted area. If used with Life this might restore the HP of a distant ally steadily over time, while Frost might emit a beam that freezes a target in place.

Step

0 Hands , 1 Action, 1 Focus

Infuse runic power into a movement, crossing physical and spatial boundaries. Move 4 spaces in a straight line, dealing minor damage to enemies or applying restoration to allies in your path.

Strike

0 Hands, 2 Action, 1 Focus

Empower a close-range attack with the essence of a Rune. This rune performs a melee weapon attack targeting the defense and dealing damage of the Rune used in the spell.

Touch

1 Hand, 1 Action, 1 Focus

Manifest the power of a Rune to pass its essence through physical contact. Used with Death this might deal damage to a target within arm's reach, while using it with Control might cause the target you touch to do your bidding.

Ward

1 Hand, 1 Action, 1 Focus

Focus the power of a Rune into a protective barrier, shielding yourselves and others from harmful effects. When used with the Kinesis rune the Ward reduces incoming damage from a chosen physical damage type while combination with the Death rune protects against Corruption damage.

Inflections.name: Inflections
Inflections.text:
Inflections are optional verbal components that modify spell effects, often amplifying or substituting certain properties a spell may have. Inflections can alter nearly any property that a Rune or Gesture provides to a spell, and may have additional effects on the spell's purpose.

While some inflections have been implemented for Playtest 1, more Inflections are intended for future phases. Some of the Inflections listed below may not be fully implemented or automated at this time.

Compose

(+1 Action, -1 Focus)

Enhance a spell by taking extra time in its formation, reducing other resource costs in exchange. The Compose inflection reduces the Focus cost of a spell by 1 while increasing its Action cost by 1 in exchange.

Determine

(+1 Focus)

Enhance a spell to make it more difficult to counter. Any attempt to Counter-Spell this spell is made with +2 Banes.

Extend

(+1 Action, +1 Focus)

Enhance the duration of a spell, increasing the duration of its effect. For spells which are instantaneous, any corresponding status conditions that they cause are increased in duration.

Effect duration increases from the Extend inflection are not yet automated in Playtest 1. This inflection is included as an example of the intended direction for the Spellcraft system.

Elude

(+1 Focus)

Enhance a spell to make it more difficult for an enemy to retaliate against its casting. This spell does not provide any opportunity to make reactions that involve Strike attacks, regardless of the results of the spell.

Negate

(+1 Focus)

Invert the effect of a spell. An Inverted Life Touch spell which normally heals a target deals Poison damage instead. An Inverted Death Ward spell inflicts vulnerability to Corruption damage upon an adjacent enemy.

The effects of the Negate inflection are not yet automated for Playtest 1. This inflection is included as an example of the intended direction for the Spellcraft system.

Pull

(+1 Focus)

Empower a spell to attract affected creatures toward the caster. Creatures affected by a spell with the Pull inflection move 1 space closer towards the spellcaster if that destination space is unoccupied.

Push

(+1 Focus)

Empower a spell to repel affected creatures away from the caster. Creatures affected by a spell with the Push inflection move 1 space away from the spellcaster if that destination space is unoccupied.

Quicken

(-1 Action, +1 Focus)

Enhance a spell by hastening the speed with which it can be cast, at the expense of increased Focus. The Quicken inflection reduces the Action cost of a spell by 1 while increasing its Focus cost by 1 in exchange.

Iconic Spells.name: Iconic Spells
Iconic Spells.text:
In addition to Composed Spells, investment into spellcraft talents unlocks Iconic Spell slots which provide a limited number of special spells which you know. These Iconic Spells have specialized effects which are not otherwise possible via the Composed Spell system and cover the breadth of magical capability that a system like Crucible requires.

Learning Iconic Spells

Each character has a certain number of Iconic Spell slots — initially zero. When learning certain spellcraft talents, you will gain an additional Iconic Spell slot which can then be populated with an Iconic Spell provided you possess the prerequisite knowledge to learn it.

Replacing Iconic Spells

When your character advances in level you may — if you wish — remove one known Iconic Spell from your repetoire, freeing that spell slot to be filled with an alternative Iconic Spell.

Countermagic.name: Countermagic
Countermagic.text:
Countermagic is the art of magical defence, weaving opposing spellcraft to negate the spell being cast by an opponent. Constructing a proper counterspell requires a degree of magical knowledge and an ability to process that knowledge in an asymmetric way, as you may not always have all the information needed to build your opposition correctly. Someone with a deep understanding of magic may be able to easily identify the telltale signs of specific Runes being used, identify a gesture, or interpret an inflection and glean the purpose of a spell. Someone practiced in Countermagic may find unique ways to disrupt a spell being cast, including sapping the magical energies from it at inception.

The Counterspell sub-system has not been included in this playtest.

Talent Tree Overview.name: Talent Tree Overview
Talent Tree Overview.text:
Talents represent unique combinations of abilities a particular character may have, and provide a level of customization and progression beyond skill advancement. Talents allow characters to define their role more clearly as they advance, growing steadily in power. Newly created characters begin with a small number of Talent Points, gaining more points at each level.

You can access the Talent Tree for a character at any time by opening the Talents tab and clicking the "Open Talent Tree" button.

Interaction with the talent tree is similar to interaction with Scenes in ordinary Foundry VTT usage. Pan the tree using right-click and drag, and use mouse-wheel to zoom in and out. Left clicking any Node will expand it to reveal the Talents it may contain.

Left-clicking a Talent purchases that talent if you have points available, while right-clicking it will remove that talent from your character.

You may reset your purchases on the Talent Tree at any time by clicking the Reset button at the bottom.

Tree Layout

Crucible's Talent Tree is divided into six sections, with each section representing a different @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6.JournalEntryPage.RHCy135mF4EN1mWZ]{Ability} which affects scaling and other aspects of those talents.

The Talent Tree is composed of several subcomponents which help you plot growth and progression for your character.

Nodes

Each sextant of the Talent tree is composed of a number of Nodes which can contain one or more Talents. A Node which lie closer to the border between two sextants will often feature abilities which relate to the themes of both ability scores.

Starting Nodes occur at the inner-most ring, and contain talents that are often prerequisites for later talents in the tree. These starter talents are best thought of as the first steps in defining what makes your character different from another in terms of their specific set of special abilities.

Talents

Talents are the smallest unit of the talent tree. Each talent grants your character-specific abilities or bonuses. Many Talents have requirements which must be met before they can be purchased, such as attaining a certain level of Ability bonus or degree of training in a Skill.

Signature Talents

Talent nodes at the outer edges of the Talent Tree contain Signature Talents, powerful bonuses that "Spellblade" or "Dread Lord" which offer iconic abilities. Signature Talents represent the culmination of the abilities required to select them, and are mirrored across two ability scores. Taking a Signature Talent forms a bridge to its paired ability score, allowing you to continue your path of progression into that sextant regardless of whether you have already purchased lower-tier Talents.

What is Crucible.name: What is Crucible
What is Crucible.text:
Crucible is an innovative and modern role-playing game (RPG) system built exclusively for Foundry Virtual Tabletop as a digital platform.

Crucible is designed from the ground up to leverage the unique capabilities of Foundry Virtual Tabletop to create exciting and fast-paced gameplay that allow gamemasters and players to focus on what matters most: telling a compelling story.

At the heart of Crucible is meaningful and empowering character advancement through a class-less system with multiple pillars of character progression. The system’s dice mechanics allow for crunchy and tactically rich encounters featuring combat, exploration, or social challenges.

Crucible is both a role-playing game and a software engine. The game system offers a deep level of mechanical sophistication, but its rules are entirely encoded to be applied with consistency and automation. The system is built intentionally to eliminate the cumbersome bookkeeping that is prevalent in high-crunch pen-and-paper systems.

Development Status

Crucible is now available for an initial Alpha Playtest which provides the community with a first look at the system, design pillars, and intended direction. The system is moderately functional, but still early in development. All areas of the system are works-in-progress and some areas are not yet developed at all. This playtest offers a chance for us to collect early feedback and share our work with the community. Please approach it with an open mind and an understanding that what you are seeing is still a long way from a finished product.

Blocks like this one in the system documentation highlight areas of the system that still require substantial development. These are intended to make you aware of areas that are intentionally unfinished at this time.

Development of Crucible is two-pronged with an equal focus on developing the system mechanics of the roleplaying game and the software implementation of those mechanics simultaneously. As the game mechanics evolve, new developments of the game system will enable those features for use in testing. The playtest process allows us to solicit and benefit from feedback that helps us iterate on the game rules and the user experience in Foundry Virtual Tabletop. We anticipate hosting multiple rounds of feedback, each focusing on a different aspect of the game experience.

Playtest One

The first playtest, @UUID[Compendium.crucible.playtest.Adventure.F8AILycmdj2kuOVa]{Playtest 1 - The Ring of Valor}, is focused on @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6]{Character Creation} and @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.QhZgmBrdLAGwYy5c]{Combat Encounters}. This playtest provides an abbreviated introduction to the Crucible game system, covering character creation, dice mechanics, combat encounters, and level advancement. The playtest begins at level 1 and advances characters through level 6 allowing them to evolve and advance their character between each challenge of the test.

Please note that the rules and mechanics featured in this playtest are not final. Most talents, skills, and rules will be further refined during later phases of development.

System Cornerstones.name: System Cornerstones
System Cornerstones.text:
Crucible is built with the following cornerstones and design principles in mind.

Consequential Character Progression

A primary goal for Crucible is to provide systems for meaningful, exciting, and impactful character progression. Creating and advancing a character in Crucible should be enjoyable and impactful as you gain access to new capabilities that tangibly evolve your playstyle and character persona.

Strategic Grid-Based Combat

Game mechanics in Crucible are designed for application to encounter or area maps with a structured grid which defines distances and positions of characters to create tactical choices about movement during combat. Movement actions and costs, engagement, flanking, cover, area-of-effect abilities, and more are all ways to add tactical nuance and dynamism to combat.

Consistently Automated Mechanics

A key goal for Crucible is to design and implement mechanics which are seamlessly automated or theoretically capable of seamless automation. We don't want automation that distracts from gameplay with the need for bookkeeping - but we also want the underlying game mechanics which are automated to be understandable to players at the table. We don't want mechanics which are inscrutable simply because we have a layer of automation in front of them. In Crucible you will find game mechanics which are elegantly and intuitively designed, but our approach to full automation of those mechanics means you can stay focused on the fun of roleplaying.

Bring Your Own Story

Crucible is optimized and designed with extended-form narrative in mind. While it can be used for one-shot adventures, the system's mechanics are intended to play out over months or years of game sessions.

Crucible provides relatively little rule-based guidance around narrative, personal character story, or the development of intrapersonal relationships - deliberately leaving these narrative pillars for the Game Master and players to explore using whatever setting or storytelling style they most prefer.

Crucible intentionally does not define a canonical setting. The system provides Gamemasters with tools to apply the system to a variety of settings. As a general rule of thumb, Crucible will work best in a gritty fantasy setting but it can be adapted for other genres and tones.

Ease of Powerful Use

Crucible is designed to be a system which is easy to learn and easy to use. Gamemasters should feel empowered to tell the stories they want to tell, and players to play the characters they want to play. We want game mechanics in Crucible to be crunchy and strategic while being presented to players in a way that is intuitive and fun to engage with.

Providing Feedback.name: Providing Feedback
Providing Feedback.text:
As part of the playtest process, we ask users to submit feedback on their experience with Crucible. This data will be collected and collated to help us identify areas of the game which need improvement, collect bugs that need to be fixed, and help us prioritize the development of new features.

Formal Feedback via Google Forms

We are not collecting feedback form responses at this time but will be re-opening the feedback form as part of a subsequent playtest update.

General Feedback via Discord

The Foundry Virtual Tabletop community Discord server is a primary hub for discussion and feedback for Foundry Virtual Tabletop, and we've configured a dedicated channel for playtest feedback. We have a dedicated channel for playtest feedback, and we encourage users to join the server and participate in the discussion. Please join the discussion in the #crucible channel of our Discord server.

License.text:
